awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Framework for Evaluation, Approximation, and Optimization of Time-Dependent Stochastic Service System Models having Deterministic/Scheduled Interventions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports establishing a mathematical framework for modeling, evaluating, approximating, and optimizing the performance of service systems featuring time-varying random as well as deterministic/scheduled input processes.  Two important example problem classes are (1) optimizing efficiency and utilization while improving patient satisfaction in healthcare facilities that treat both time-varying randomly-arriving patients (e.g., emergent or walk-in) as well as patients having scheduled appointments (e.g., primary-care-physician referrals, school-required physical exams, or scheduled vaccinations), and (2) optimizing efficiency and utilization while improving flexibility and responsiveness to global competition in manufacturing facilities that operate in both a time-varying stochastic (e.g., production) environment as well as a deterministic/scheduled (e.g., job-release schedule) environment.  The solution to a unified abstraction of both problem classes requires modeling and analysis methods that allow rich variations in model-input processes, and model logic, while adequately capturing the time-dependent evolution of the resulting probabilistic network. Traditional (exact) time-dependent differential-difference equation modeling of such networks is infeasible since the number of differential-difference equations describing even modest-sized networks can be of the order of hundreds of thousands (or more). Monte Carlo (MC) computer simulation, the natural alternative choice, is convenient but burdened with slow convergence rates and additional mathematically technical inefficiencies.   Methods investigated by the research team will assist healthcare (and other) service and manufacturing sector industries to increase their economic competitiveness and patient/customer, satisfaction.


The research will result in closure-equipped partial moment differential equations (PMDEs) for numerically approximating the time-dependent evolution of general stochastic networks having scheduled interventions. By exploiting the structure of PMDEs, and then strategically using closure approximations, the research team will be able to efficiently describe the time-dependent evolution of very general networks.  Preliminary evidence indicates that the time-dependent evolution of modest stochastic networks can be approximated to machine accuracy within a few seconds on a typical laptop computer.  Moreover, higher order derivatives, which often require significant effort in the Monte Carlo context, can be obtained with little to no extra effort by exploiting the rich structure inherent in the approximations.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this project include establishing a mathematical framework and software for modeling, evaluating, approximating, and optimizing the performance of service systems featuring time-varying stochastic as well as
deterministic/scheduled input processes and structures. The following two example settings serve to illustrate the types of questions and contexts of relevance.

I. Appointment and Capacity Scheduling:  Suppose a facility services two types of patients: time-varying random arrivals corresponding to patients having semi-emergent circumstances, and scheduled arrivals corresponding to non-emergent patients who arrive at a time specified through a prior appointment. Depending on the nature of the facility, scheduled arrivals can either be the predominant population, e.g., an MRI facility, or the less dominant group, e.g., in a pharmacy walk-in clinic. Assume that patients are served according to a specified priority rule, and that the arrival process of the random arrivals and the population-wide service process follow some general time-varying probability law. Within this context numerous important questions may be asked. Can the functioning of the facility as measured by some reasonable overall measure of congestion (e.g., virtual integrated waiting time over a time horizon) be evaluated or approximated with provable guarantees? Can the
deterministic arrivals be scheduled in such a way that a chosen congestion measure is minimized? If it is known that the facility in question is to lose capacity, when should such reduction in capacity be scheduled so as to minimize the resulting effect on the chosen congestion measure? What is the minimum number of healthcare workers (in each shift) to ensure that a specified service level is met?

II. Manufacturing Production and Scheduling:  Consider the context of a large manufacturing network comprising a set of nodes (or resources) engaged in various stages of manufacturing a set of products. Manufacturing each product thus involves raw material undergoing a unique and often elaborate sequence of operations at some subset of the nodes within the network. It is common that production planners within such facilities, towards meeting manufacturing demands for each product, have a set of production runs planned for the week. External to such ``regular" demand, and in order to increase the enterprise's flexibility in meeting quick-turn-around special-request orders, production planners also schedule, at the beginning of each week, a set of special runs at a subset of nodes to meet special-request demands. Questions analogous to those asked for the previous example can be asked in this context. Can the time-varying stochastic output of the manufacturing network be evaluated (or numerically approximated to provable accuracy)? How should the special request demands be scheduled so as to maximize some reasonable time-dependent measure of the manufacturing network's output? If some subset of resources within the network are to be decommissioned for maintenance, when should such capacity reduction happen to minimize the ill-effects on a chosen throughput measure? How much and what type of additional capacity should be added to ensure that a specified probabilistic service level is met?

The challenges associated with answering the type of questions we have posed are noteworthy: (i) the time-varying arrival and service processes can be general implying the absence of closed-form expressions and the consequent need for numerical approximation; (ii) the number of patients (or ``entities") to be scheduled may be numerous, implying the need for high-dimensional estimation and optimization in the face of randomness; and (iii) constraints on scheduling times, as might happen for elective surgery and block scheduling, might exist and complicate the optimization procedure.

The outcomes of our three-year investigation into the above questions fall within two categories: (i) algorithm and software for mixed-integer stochastic optimization problems; and (ii) theories on optimal sampling for stochastic optimization.

In (i), a concrete outcome of the project is the development of ADALine, a mixed-integer stochastic optimization algorithm capable of solving abstracted versions of the questions raised within the two application contexts previously discussed. ADALine should be viewed as a stochastic mixed-integer version of what might be considered the most reliable deterministic (local continuous) optimization algorithm that exists today. Testing and development of software based on ADALine is ongoing with promising early indications.

In (ii), that is, theories on optimal sampling for stochastic optimization, our investigation led to what appear to be general principles of optimal algorithmic sampling within stochastic optimization algorithms. These principles are general in the sense of applying to wide-ranging and large-scale contexts, while also concrete in that they are in the form of mathematical laws for optimal sampling. In addition to being interesting in their own right, the utility of these laws lies in serving as directives for algorithm development,
by providing a sense of whether a given algorithm has room for improvement in terms of the ability to converge to a solution faster.
